text:
Therapist: Good morning. I'm Dr. Rogers, you must be Gloria. (They shake hands and sit down.)
Patient: Yes, I am.
Therapist: Won't you have a chair? Now then, we have half an hour together, and I really don't know what we will be able to make of it, but uh I hope we can make something of it. I'd be glad to know whatever concerns you.
Patient: Well, right now I'm nervous (T: Mhm) but I feel more comfortable the way you are talking in a low voice and I don't feel like you'll be so harsh on me. But, ah ...
Therapist: I hear the tremor in your voice so I know you are... (C: Smiles)

Patient: Uh, well, the main thing I want to talk to you about is uh, I'm just newly divorced and uh I had gone in therapy before and I felt comfortable when I left, and all of a sudden now the biggest change is adjusting to my single life. (T: Mhm, mhm) And uh one of the things that bothers me the most is especially men, and having men to the house and how it affects the children (T: Mhm, Mhm) and- Uh, the biggest thing I want - the thing that keeps coming to my mind I want to tell you about is that I have a daughter, nine, who at one time I felt had a lot of emotional problems. I wish I could stop shaking (T and C: laugh). And uh, I'm real conscious of things affecting her. I don't want her to get upset, I don't want to shock her. I want so bad to- for her to accept me. And we're real open with each other especially about sex. And the other day she saw a girl that was single but pregnant and she asked me all about 'can girls get pregnant if they are single?'

Therapist: And it's this concern about her and the fact that you really aren't - that this open relationship that has existed between you, now you feel it's kind of vanished?
Patient: Yes. I feel like I have to be on guard about that (T: Mhm) because I remember when I was a little girl, when I first found out my mother and father made love, that was dirty and terrible, and I didn't- I didn't like her any more for a while. And I don't want to lie to Pammy either and I don't know...
Therapist: I sure wish I could give you the answer as to what you should tell her. (Smiles.)
Patient: I was afraid you were going to say that (Laughs).
Therapist: Because what you really want is an answer.
Patient: I want to especially know if it would affect her if I was completely honest and open with her or if it would affect her because I lied. I feel like it is bound to make a strain because I lied to her. [Words lost]

Therapist: Mhm. You feel she'll suspect that, or she'll know something is not quite right?
Patient: I feel that in time she will distrust me, yes (T: Mhm, mhm). And also I thought well, gee, what about when she gets a little older and she finds herself in touchy situations. She probably wouldn't want to admit it to me because she thinks I'm so good and so sweet. (Points to herself.) And yet I'm afraid she could think I'm really a- a devil. And I want so bad for her to accept me. And I don't know how much a nine-year-old can take.
Therapist: And really both alternatives concern you. That she may think you're too good or better than you really are.
Patient: Yes.
Therapist: And she may think you are worse than you are.
Patient: Not worse than I am. (Smiles) I don't know if she can accept me the way I am. I think I paint a picture that I'm all sweet and motherly. And -- I'm a little ashamed of my shady side too. (T:Mhm, mhm)

Therapist: I see. It really cuts a little deeper. If she really knew you, would she, could she accept you?
Patient: This is what I don't know. Yeah. I don't want her to turn away from me. And I don't even know how I feel about it because there are times when I feel so guilty like when I have a man over, I even try to make a special set-up so that if I were ever alone with him, the children would never catch me in that sort of thing.  Because I'm real leery about it (T: Mhm).  And yet I also know that I have these desires.
Therapist: And so itâ€™s quite clear it isn't only her problem or the relationship with her, it's in you as well.
Patient: And my guilt. Yeah. Yeah. (T: Oh) I feel guilty so often. (Moistens lips.)
Therapist: 'What- What can I accept myself as doing?' And uh (C: Yes, Yes) you realize that you set up sort of subterfuges, so as to make sure that you're not caught or something, you realize that you are acting from guilt, is that it?

Patient: Yes (T: Mhm, mhm) and I don't like the ... I would like to feel comfortable with whatever I do. If I choose not to tell Pammy the truth, to feel comfortable that she can handle it, (T: Mhm, Mhm, Mhm) and I don't. I want to be honest, and yet I feel there are some areas that I don't even accept (T: Mhm, Mhm).
Therapist: And if you can't accept them in yourself, how could you possibly be comfortable in telling them to her?
Patient: Right.
Therapist: Mhm. Mhm. And yet, as you say, you do have these desires and you do have your feelings, but- but you don't feel good about them.
Patient: Right. (T: Nods and smiles.) (Pause) And I, I, I have a feeling that you are just going to sit there and let me stew in it (laughs) and I- I want more. I want you to help me get rid of my guilt feeling. If I can get rid of my guilt feeling about lying or going to bed with a single man, any of that, just so I can feel more comfortable.

Therapist: Mhm. And I guess I'd like to say, 'No, I don't want to let you stew in your feelings,' but on the other hand, I, I also feel that this is the kind of very private thing that I couldn't possibly answer for you. But I sure as anything will try to help you work toward your own answer. I don't know whether that makes any sense to you, but I mean it.

Patient: Well, I appreciate you saying that. (Takes her arm off back of chair, now uses both hands to gesture.) You sound like you mean it. But I don't know where to go. (T: Mhm, Mhm, Mhm) I don't begin to know where to go. I thought that I had pretty well worked over most of my guilt, and now that this is coming up I'm disappointed in myself. (T: Mhm, Mhm) I really am. I want- I like it when I feel that no matter what I do, even if it's against my mother's morals or my upbringing, that I can still feel okay about me. And now I don't. Uh, there's a part of me that who sort of mother me. And now I don't.  Like uh, there's a girl at work who sort of mothers. me and she just- she- I think she thinks I'm all sweet, and I sure don't want to show my more ornery devilish side with her.  I want to be sweet and it's so hard for me to - this all seems so new again (T: Mhm) and it's so disappointing.

Therapist: Yeah, I get the disappointment - that here, a lot of these things youâ€™d thought youâ€™d worked through, and now the guilts and the feeling that only a part of you is acceptable to anybody else.
Patient: Yes.
Therapist: That keeps coming out. (Pause) (C: Strains eyebrows.) I guess I do catch the real deep puzzlement that you feel as to 'What the hell shall I do? What can I do?'

Patient: Yes, and do you know what I can find, doctor, (Touches forehead.) is that everything I start to do that I st- impulsive, seems natural to tell Pammy, or- or to go out on a date or something, Iâ€™m comfortable until I think how I was affected as a child and the minute that comes up, then Iâ€™m all haywire. (T: Mhm) Like uh, I want to be a good mother so bad, and I feel like I am a good mother, (T: Mhm) but then thereâ€™s those little exceptions. Like my guilts with working. I want to work and itâ€™s so fun having extra money. I like to work nights. The minute I think Iâ€™m not being real good to the children or giving them enough time, then I start feeling guilty again. Then, thatâ€™s when I- itâ€™s uh- what do they call it? (Looks away briefly.) A double bind. Thatâ€™s just what it feels like. I want to do this and it feels right, but after all Iâ€™m not being a good mother and I want to be both. I am becoming more and more aware of what a perfectionist I am. That is what it

it feels like. I want to do this and it feels right, but after all Iâ€™m not being a good mother and I want to be both. I am becoming more and more aware of what a perfectionist I am. That is what it seems I want to be so perfect. Either I want to become perfect in my standards, or not have that need any more.

Therapist: Or, I guess I hear it a little differently - that uh- what you want is to seem perfect, but it means itâ€™s - a great- a matter of great importance to you to be a good mother and you want to seem to be a good mother, even if some of your actual feelings differ from that. (Points to C.) Is that catching it or not?
Patient: Gee, I donâ€™t feel like I am saying that. (T: Oh, okay) No, that isnâ€™t what I feel, really. I want to approve of me always, but my actions wonâ€™t let me. I want to approve of me. (Pause) I â€“ I think- (Strains face.)
Therapist: I realize ... you â€“ alright, but let me -- Iâ€™d like to understand it. You sound as though your actions were kind of outside of you. You want to approve of you, but what you do somehow wonâ€™t let you approve of yourself.

Patient: Right. (Pause) Like I feel that I canâ€™t approve of myself regarding, for example (Smiles.), my sex life. (T: Mhm, Mhm) This is the big thing. If I really fell in love with a man and I respected him and I adored him, I donâ€™t think I would feel so guilty about sex. And I donâ€™t know why I would want to make up any excuses to why this is true. (T: Mhm, Mhm) I really am. I want- I like it when I feel that no matter when I have the physical desires and Iâ€™ll say, 'Oh well, why not,' and I want to anyway, but I feel guilty afterwards. I hate facing the kids, I donâ€™t like looking at myself, and I rarely enjoy it. And this is what I mean. If the circumstances would be different, I donâ€™t think Iâ€™d feel so guilty because Iâ€™d feel right about it. (Gestures more profoundly.)

Therapist: Yeah, I- I guess I hear you saying, 'If what I was doing, when I went to bed with a man, was really genuine and full of love and respect and so on, I wouldnâ€™t feel guilty in relation to Pam. I wouldnâ€™t uh, I, I really would be comfortable about the situation.'
Patient: Thatâ€™s how I feel, yeah. (Smiles.) And I know that sounds like I want a perfect situation, but that is how I feel. And in the meantime, I canâ€™t stop these desires. I tried that also. Iâ€™ve tried saying, 'O.K., I donâ€™t like myself when I do that so I wonâ€™t do it any more.' But then I resent the children. I think, why should they stop me from doing what I want, and it is really not that bad.
Therapist: But I guess I heard you saying too, that it isnâ€™t only the children, but you donâ€™t like it as well when it isnâ€™t really ...

Therapist: But I guess I heard you saying too, that it isnâ€™t only the children, but you donâ€™t like it as well when it isnâ€™t really ...
Patient: Right. Iâ€™m sure that - I know thatâ€™s it, probably even more so than Iâ€™m aware of. But I only notice it so much when I pick it up in the children. Then I can also notice it in myself. (Touches her face.)
Therapist: And somehow, sometimes, you kind of uh, feel like blaming them for the feelings you have. I mean, why should they cut you out from a normal sex life, huh?
Patient: Well, a sex life, I could say, not normal because there is something about me that says thatâ€™s not very healthy â€“ to uh just go into sex because you feel physically attracted or something, or a physical need. So, something about it tells me that thatâ€™s not quite right anyway. (Still touching her face.)
Therapist: Mhm. (Pause) But you feel, really, that at times youâ€™re acting in ways that are not in accord with your own inner standards.

Therapist: Mhm. (Pause) But you feel, really, that at times youâ€™re acting in ways that are not in accord with your own inner standards.
Patient: Right. Right.
Therapist: But then you were also saying, a minute ago, that you feel you canâ€™t help that uh- either.

Patient: I wish I could. Thatâ€™s it, and I canâ€™t - now I feel like I- I canâ€™t control myself as well as I could have before. For a specific reason now, I canâ€™t. I just let go and I have- thereâ€™s too many things I do wrong that I have to feel guilty for, and I sure donâ€™t like that. I want you very much to give me a direct answer, and Iâ€™m going to ask it, and I donâ€™t expect a direct answer, (Smiles.) but I want to know. Do you feel that - to me the most important thing is to be open and honest and if I can be open and honest with my children, do you feel that it could harm them?  If for example, I could say to Pammy, "I was- I felt bad lying to you, Pammy, and I want to tell you the truth now," and if I tell her the truth and sheâ€™s shocked at me and sheâ€™s upset, that that could bother her more?  I was- I want to get rid of my guilts and that will help me, but I don't want to put â€˜em on her.
